title: i have to ask. whats the difference between a silver maokai/renekton and a diamond one?
body:
other than game knowledge their laning is gonna go the same and their teamfighting will probably become the same way as well.

so how exactly do these champs not carry people who themselves dont belong in that elo they are winning in?

ive seen maokai and janna mains play a different champ like thresh or riven and go 0-10 .

replies.body: Skill.
maokai? ok...
ask an obvious question, get an obvious answer
uve obviously never played maokai if you think theres a skill difference in champ gameplay between a silver or a diamodn

> [{quoted}](name=AzureRaven,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=sriAE7pV,comment-id=0001000000000000,timestamp=2016-06-22T23:19:57.173+0000)
>
> uve obviously never played maokai if you think theres a skill difference in champ gameplay between a silver or a diamodn

Think this is unnecessarily inflammatory. There's definitely differences in how well a person plays a champion across tiers. Even one as seemingly simple as Maokai. 

I will say that sometimes the mechanical differences between a Diamond and a Silver are oversold. However, there are a lot of things I'd expect from a Diamond Maokai player that I wouldn't from Silver. 

On the more tactical, mechanical side: 

* Last hitting : I expect a better Mao to get more CS, whether that's through skill ability patterns (E/Q for backline) or knowing his thresholds for killing minions
* Passive usage : Would expect a higher tier Maokai to pay more attention to this, and get more passive procs off especially as you get into team fights
* Trading up in lane with Q use to disengage
* Increase his threat level around turret by having better W -> Q combos to knock enemies back into turrets
* Better mana management, in particular around ultimate usage

At a more strategic level, I'd expect the Diamond Mao to be better at: 

* Building appropriately for their lane / game match-up
* Wave management with abilities : maybe it's not always the best idea to permapush with E/Q
* Better teleport plays and control over bottom lane
* Understanding of when to engage and what is a good engage

there are meta builds that are shown on websites as well like probuilds.net and such. as for laning, most maokai  players play it super safe so they dont die and such and are able to cs. as for csing for low elos, they still manage to scrape some gold up and can get gold from teamfights and such.  i dont think silver players are going to have a hard time following their lanes tp when they can just tp themselves to that specific lane. mana management for maokai is almsot impossible to screw up seeing as he has low mana usage and he doesnt need to spam his skills to do damage and such.

> [{quoted}](name=AzureRaven,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=sriAE7pV,comment-id=000100000000000000010000,timestamp=2016-06-22T23:56:09.324+0000)
>
> there are meta builds that are shown on websites as well like probuilds.net and such.

There is no one build that works in every game, especially for tanks. The "Most Frequent Core Build" on champion.gg for Maokai top was only used in 564 games out of 13,882. That isn't even accounting for how many of those 564 games were uncompleted builds that may have diverted had that game gone on longer.

If you look at probuilds.net the first thing you immediately notice is that pros do not build champions the same as other pros, they don't even build the same as they did the last time they played that champion.

> [{quoted}](name=AzureRaven,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=sriAE7pV,comment-id=000100000000000000010000,timestamp=2016-06-22T23:56:09.324+0000)
>
> there are meta builds that are shown on websites as well like probuilds.net and such. as for laning, most maokai  players play it super safe so they dont die and such and are able to cs. as for csing for low elos, they still manage to scrape some gold up and can get gold from teamfights and such.  i dont think silver players are going to have a hard time following their lanes tp when they can just tp themselves to that specific lane. mana management for maokai is almsot impossible to screw up seeing as he has low mana usage and he doesnt need to spam his skills to do damage and such.

silver players aren't going to  make plays where it counts to win that extra 10-25%  of games.

would you give up toplane tower vs 2/0 nasus as maokai to go get a wind dragon for example?

decisions like this can make or break

> [{quoted}](name=AzureRaven,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=sriAE7pV,comment-id=0001000000000000,timestamp=2016-06-22T23:19:57.173+0000)
>
> I've obviously never played maokai

FTFY
{{champion:50}} How obvious.
Decision making is stronger than skill with a champion.

you can pretty much autopilot on maokai .. you focus the carry in teamfights and peel for adc with your ulti. 

i first timed janna and fell asleep. she is beyond braindead and is rewarded for it heavily.

You can do well with Janna in lane, but what if you could have roamed and saved your mid during a gank or an engage on the enemy midlaner?

There's a lot of micro decisions that can go into turning a game in your favor that are in no way relative to skill.
uhh.. you go mid, press e on the mid and if they try to chase you press r and q them away. if they get within w range you press w. its not hard at all.

I think you are missing the point.  I'm not saying it's hard.  It's that during a game a lot of players fall into the same patterns.  The ability to be flexible in decisions, especially good ones, will turn a game in your favor.  You can say most champions in the game are easy and require little thought, but it's the decisions you make that allow you to climb in ranking.
Mechanics are 20% of your rank, decision making is 80%.

Same can be said for Blitzcrank, but decisions like teleporting in to help bot lane or tp back top to get farm which could result in a positive/negative game changer. One choice can decide a team fight or even the game.

Champions vary in skill, there are some for new players such as Annie or some for experienced players like Cassiopeia.

Decision-making would make the difference. Maokai always has a mediocre win rate despite his power because you need to think with him.

And I don't get this sentence: "ive seen maokai and janna mains play a different champ like thresh or riven and go 0-10" at all. Of course a Janna player would do terribly on Riven if they're not also a Riven main - Riven is hard as hell and could not be more different from the most defensive, peely support in the game. Why would you ever expect a defensive mage support player to be adept at an extremely aggressive fighter, who also happens to require extreme dedication to learn? A Riven main would do horribly on Orianna if they randomly picked her up but that wouldn't mean the Riven player can't play hard champions, it just means the Riven player is naturally doing badly on a champion that isn't their usual style and is also very difficult to learn.

It'd be a more valid comparison if you said "I've seen Janna players try to pick up Nami and do terribly even after spending loads of time trying to learn her", but Riven is too different a champion to the champions you listed and most people do terribly on her until they have a fair few Riven games under their belt.

> i have to ask. whats the difference between a silver maokai/renekton and a diamond one?

There are a million things to concentrate on in LoL.
Better players are better at doing more of those than worse players.

I also feel like you're confusing using 5 abilities well with mastering the millions of things in LoL. 

Knowing how a Q works isn't going to help with knowing where the enemy jungler is, how to effectively trade, when to trade, how much you can get away with doing, when to push, when to freeze, how to get amazing CS, resource management, when to back, when to roam, when to team fight, were to pressure other lanes, how to push your advantage, how to recover from a disadvantage...

Silver players have a general idea of these things, but are pretty fuzzy on the specifics.
Diamond players will have a clearer idea of when and how to do many of these things.

You really are the whiniest person on these boards.
if whining meant asking a question i actually wanted to know the answer too, then ok. but by all means keep wasting time commenting that shit

> [{quoted}](name=AzureRaven,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=sriAE7pV,comment-id=00060000,timestamp=2016-06-23T00:31:34.494+0000)

Okay sensitive whiny boy.
ok guy hiding behind unranked smurf account but wont show his rank to avoid detection

>whats the difference between a silver maokai/renekton and a diamond one? 

9am-5pm

game knowledge is actually a big deal. Today I went up against a silver fiora as cait. She whined the whole time while screwing herself over and over again. I didn't even kill her most of the time I just abused the free minion control because she didn't possess basic game knowledge. I lost every duel we had except the few where she made silver-ish mistakes I could exploit. I don't even play cait that often.

It all comes down to snowball knowledge, matchup knowledge and general understanding of the game. I expect a silver player to not know shit about what's the point in freezing a lane, how to do it, when to do it, why, how to zone out someone of minions, how to get better map awareness, how to snowball one's team, when to roam, why, what is the proper way to get objectives, get a splitpush going, understanding how the wave of minions work out, understanding why a dive is efficient and when, when it is not, when a tradekill is worth and when it isn't, and, but that's quite a gimmick, a diamond would be better mechanically (but who cares, the other things are much more important).
Difference between diamond and silver is game knowledge. People who think this is all linked to mechanics are usually low elo or arrogant good mechanical players around plat which can't climb because they start lacking in the game knowledge department.

and the differnce between a  silver {{champion:76}}  and a diamond {{champion:76}} , is that diamond nid actaulyl have the mechanics to not get executed in the jungle. or rather not be at such low HP that the enemy jungler can invade you and kill you with 1 auto.

Guys, do not waste too much time on players asking these question in the future. A lot of lower tier players do not see the significance of each decision and micro parts of the gaming that they just assume they're just as good. Obviously, they are not even good enough, to understand that they are not good enough.
